p: The addition of a targeted, dry season insecticide application, in addition to the standard MoH procedures, is associated with a reduction of dengue incidence. Clinical reports of dengue and rainfall are compared for 1999–2014 in Fig 1. The period 1999–2005 preceded the dry-season intervention ( Fig 1A), which was implemented during 2006–2012 ( Fig 1B). Rainfall patterns remained seasonal and consistent with historical norms for the 8-year period. The additional pre-season fogging in 2006 was followed by a reduction of dengue cases during the subsequent rainy season ( Fig 1B). Based on this result, pre-seasonal surveys and interventions continued in 2007 with surveys and fogging at the end of the dry season ( Fig 1B), in addition to routine MoH activities.
